title: A soft power strategy to preserve non-sovereignty from Chinese land claims on the moon
summary:

Similar to Apollo and the space race with the Soviet Union, the principle of non-sovereignty is at issue as is the rule-based international order. The issue of non-sovereignty in […]

title: Second Space Resources Challenge: from concept to reality at LUNA
summary: Last year, ESA invited innovators across Europe to join the second Space Resources Challenge, a competition designed to accelerate technologies that will help humankind live and work sustainably on the Moon.
detailed_news: ESA invited innovators across Europe to join the second Space Resources Challenge. The challenge is designed to accelerate technologies that will help humankind live and work sustainably on the Moon. Last week, eight teams demonstrated robotic systems capable of collecting and processing lunar soil. The winning team is expected to be announced at the end of November. Team ASTROLITH developed Kirb-e, a robotic system built for Moon-like conditions designed to dig and sort lunar soil. Using a rover equipped with rotating shovels, the team successfully collected and processed large quantities of regolith simulant. The material was then funneled into a rotary sieve to separate it by particle size. The rover collects lunar soil using a rotating tube, which also acts as the internal storage in which it remains. To reduce the risk of dust interfering with moving parts, they sealed the chassis and minimised exposed mechanisms. Although they faced challenges with motor drivers and software integration, the team was proud to complete and test their system.

title: Focusing on NGC 3370
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: The galaxy is called NGC 3370, and it is a spiral galaxy located nearly 90 million light-years away in the constellation Leo(The Lion) It is home to two kinds of objects that astronomers prize for their usefulness in determining distances to faraway galaxies: Cepheid variable stars and Type Ia supernovae.

title: Airbus, Thales, and Leonardo Agree to Create European Space Behemoth
summary:
European aerospace giants Airbus, Leonardo, and Thales have signed a memorandum of understanding to combine their respective space businesses into a single new company. Ownership will be shared among the three parent firms, with Leonardo and Thales each holding a 32.5% stake, and Airbus holding the majority stake of 35%. The new company, which will […]
The post Airbus, Thales, and Leonardo Agree to Create European Space Behemoth appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: Airbus, Leonardo, and Thales have signed a memorandum of understanding to combine their respective space businesses into a single new company. Ownership will be shared among the three parent firms, with Leonardo each holding a 32.5% stake, and Airbus holding the majority stake of 35%. The new company, which will employ approximately 25,000 people, will be managed jointly under a “balanced governance structure”

title: Airbus, Leonardo and Thales agree to form new European company
summary: This new entity would potentially come online in 2027, pending regulatory approval and other logistics. A name for this combination hasn’t been announced.
detailed_news: Airbus, Leonardo and Thales announce a memorandum of understanding on Thursday to combine forces in a new entity. The new, yet-to-be-named company aims to come online in 2027, pending regulatory approval and other logistics. Airbus would own a majority of this new venture with a 35 percent stake. Aschbacher said he is not “concerned in terms of diversity and competition” “We will certainly adapt to the new situation. We will support them in their buildup of the new company,” he said. The launch will be managed by Arianespace and will carry the third satellite for the Optical Space Component.

title: NASA leadership battle intensifies as Trump weighs Isaacman vs. Duffy
summary:
A high-stakes contest for NASA’s next permanent Administrator is unfolding, pitting billionaire private astronaut Jared…
The post NASA leadership battle intensifies as Trump weighs Isaacman vs. Duffy appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: Jared Isaacman is a billionaire entrepreneur, two-time private astronaut, and philanthropist known for raising over $250 million for St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital during the Inspiration4 mission. Isaacman cleared a significant hurdle on April 9, 2025, passing the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation with a 19-9 vote. But political turbulence derailed the process. NASA was left with Petro as Acting Administrator and no permanent replacement in sight. In a surprising turn, Trump appointed Secretary of Transportation Sean Duffy as NASA’s new Acting Administrator in July 2025. Duffy, a close ally of the President, received unexpected support from Isaacman, who even flew Duffy in his MiG-29 fighter jet.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to expend Falcon 9 booster to launch Spainsat NG 2 communications satellite
summary: The SpainSat NG 2 satellite will be flown to a geosynchronous transfer orbit. Liftoff is scheduled during a four-hour window that opens at 9:30 p.m. EDT (0130 UTC).
detailed_news: A SpaceX Falcon 9 first stage flew Thursday for the 21st and final time. The rocket wasn’t fitted with landing legs or grid fins as they were not needed. This was the 134th orbital launch of 2025 for SpaceX, tying the total number of launches it achieved for all of 2024. The launch was originally scheduled for Wednesday night, but was delayed 24 hours for reasons not disclosed. SpaceX's first full-size stainless steel Starship test vehicle stands some 164 feet tall and measures wider than the cabin of a Boeing 747 jumbo jet. If Elon Musk has his way, it will fly to an altitude of 65,000 feet before the end of the year. SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket with 60 Starlink internet satellites.

detailed_news: Avio shareholders approved a proposal to initiate a €400 million capital increase during an extraordinary shareholders’ meeting on Thursday. The company’s board was also delegated the authority to execute a future capital raise without seeking further shareholder approval. Under the approved proposal, Avio will have 12 months to complete the capital raise.

title: Earth from space: Likouala-aux-Herbes river, Congo
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: This Copernicus Sentinel-2 image captures the meandering course of the Likouala-aux-Herbes river in the Republic of the Congo. The region is covered with permanent swamp and marsh, dense forests and grassland, which also explains the origin of the river’s name, meaning 'grassy river'

title: FutureEO at ESA’s Ministerial Council 2025
summary: The European Space Agency’s Council at Ministerial Level is the time for bold vision and decisive action. In November, ESA’s Member States, Associate States, and Cooperating States will unite to elevate Europe’s role in space and secure its continued leadership for the benefit of citizens.
detailed_news: The European Space Agency’s Council at Ministerial Level is the time for bold vision and decisive action. FutureEO is a driving force for innovation and excellence across satellite missions, Earth system science and Earth action. To date, seven Earth Explorer missions have been launched successfully. FutureEO will be structured around three pillars: Foundations, Missions and Data, and Earth Action. The Foundations pillar is the engine that powers every future Earth observation mission. It lays the groundwork for science, technology and mission preparation. The Earth Action pillar turns Earth observation into real-world impact, delivering benefits for science and society. The Next Generation Gravity Mission will provide unmatched insight into how ‘mass’ moves within the Earth system. WIVERN is the eleventh mission to be selected for implementation as an Earth Explorer. The Climate Change Initiative , EO for Society and the Global Development Assistance element will now be integrated into Earth Action.

summary: The Republic of Cyprus has signed an Associate Agreement with the European Space Agency, and is expected to become an Associate Member in the coming months.
detailed_news: The Republic of Cyprus has signed an Associate Agreement with the European Space Agency. Cyprus will proceed with ratification and plans to achieve associate membership by early 2026, during its Presidency of the Council of the European Union. With Cyprus's ratification, ESA will have four active Associate Member states: Cyprus, Latvia, Lithuania, and Slovakia.

title: Condensation defying gravity
summary: From dew at dawn to a foggy mirror after a shower, condensation is part of our daily lives on Earth. In space, microgravity alters how heat flows through gases and liquids, a potential enemy for spacecraft electronics needing to cool down in extreme environments.
detailed_news: Condensation on Fins experiment is pioneering heat transfer tests in orbit to study the role of capillary pressure – the force that pulls liquids through tiny spaces. Results will have practical applications, such as cooling electronics in smartphones and computers, and optimising industrial coating processes on our planet. The Condensation on Fins experiment is part of a larger round of tests on heat transfer in gases and liquids. It all happens inside the new Heat Transfer Host 2 facility, installed on 30 September 2025 after its delivery on the 23rd Northrop Grumman cargo resupply mission to the International Space Station.

detailed_news: Irish space electronics company Réaltra Space Systems Engineering has been awarded a €1.5 million contract by ArianeGroup. The VIKI system will provide live video telemetry during all phases of an Ariane 6 launch. The system is built primarily from Commercial Off-The-Shelf (COTS) equipment originally designed for terrestrial aerospace use.

title: Relativity completes Terran R thrust section, continues testing ahead of first launch
summary:
While SpaceX’s Falcon family continues to demonstrate reliable reuse of its first stages and fairings,…
The post Relativity completes Terran R thrust section, continues testing ahead of first launch appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: Relativity Space’s Terran R rocket is under construction in Long Beach, California. The company recently showed good progress in working toward the vehicle's first flight, which is now scheduled for late next year. The thrust section of the Terran R is one of the most intricate and complex parts of the vehicle. During testing, the thrust structure withstood 3.7 million pound-force (lbf) of tension. The thrust structure for Terran R’s second flight is now under construction, along with critical avionics for the first flight. All eight structural barrels of the first stage were welded by the end of August, and the company has started welding them together to form the first-stage body. The two structural barrels for the second stage were finished in August as well. The 82 m tall Terran R is scheduled to launch in the second half of 2026. The partially reusable vehicle is designed to compete with other partially reusable vehicles like Falcon 9 and Neutron. Terran R’s first stage will land on an automated landing ship downrange after launch.

summary: The Starlink 11-5 mission will be the 95th flight in 2025 supporting the low Earth orbit internet constellation. Liftoff from pad 4E at Vandenberg Space Force Base is scheduled for 7:16 a.m. PDT (10:16 a.m. EDT / 1416 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX is preparing to launch its 550th Falcon 9 mission since the rocket's debut in 2010. The launch from California will add 28 more broadband internet satellites to the company's Starlink constellation. The 28 Starlink V2 Mini satellites will be deployed from the Falcon 9 rocket’s second stage about an hour after liftoff.

title: Sounding the alarm: ESA introduces space environment ‘health index’
summary: The congestion and pollution of Earth orbit is quickly getting worse. We need to be able to quantify how our behaviour impacts the orbital environment in the future. To this end, the European Space Agency (ESA) is adding a new health index to its yearly Space Environment Report that summarises in one number the status of our space environment over time.
detailed_news: The Space Environment Health Index measures how sustainable Earth’s orbital environment is. A high score indicates a greater negative impact on the environment, while a low score reflects more sustainable behaviour. A value of 1 represents the proposed threshold for long-term sustainability. Anything higher means that the space environment becomes less then desirable for operations over time. We are now at Health Index level 4, far beyond the sustainability threshold. Stronger action is required to protect our future in space. The index is more than a scientific tool – it is a practical decision-making aid. It can be applied to mission design to minimise its environmental impact.

title: Elon Musk just declared war on NASA’s acting administrator, apparently
summary: "Sean said that NASA might benefit from being part of the Cabinet."
detailed_news: SpaceX founder Elon Musk referred to the interim head of the space agency, Sean Duffy, as “Sean Dummy” Musk later added, “The person responsible for America’s space program can’t have a 2 digit IQ.” This is all pretty bonkers, so I want to try to contextualize what I believe is going on behind the scenes. NASA administrator Sean Duffy said he was reworking the agency’s lunar lander contracts because SpaceX had fallen behind. Duffy sought to demonstrate to the rest of the space community that he was willing to stand up to SpaceX. Musk channeled his inner Trump and called out ‘Sean Dummy’ A fierce, behind-the-scenes battle rages on among camps supporting Duffy and Isaacman to decide the leadership of NASA. In the meantime, NASA is twisting in the wind, trying to run in molasses while wearing lead shoes as China marches onward and upward.

title: NASA Opens Competition for Artemis III Lunar Lander
summary:
NASA Acting Administrator Sean Duffy revealed that the agency is reopening the contract for the…
The post NASA Opens Competition for Artemis III Lunar Lander appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: NASA is reopening the contract for the first U.S. crewed lunar landing since the 1970s. The decision marks a significant shift in NASA’s Artemis program, which seeks to establish a sustainable human presence on the Moon. The move aims to accelerate the Artemis III mission and ensure American astronauts return to the Moon's surface. SpaceX CEO Elon Musk downplayed the urgency of beating China, advocating instead for long-term sustainability. Lockheed Martin indicated it has been quietly developing a “safe solution to return humans to the Moon as quickly as possible” The announcement has left many questions unanswered, including the timeline for the new competition, proposal deadlines, and funding sources.

detailed_news: The European Space Shield is a new initiative aimed at protecting space assets and services against ‘growing threats’ The initiative will complement the dual-use space capabilities provided by the European Union. SpaceX is supplying optical terminals to Muon Space, the four-year-old Californian manufacturer said Oct. 21, enabling its future Halo satellites to use the Starlink broadband constellation as a global data-relay network.
The post Starlink mini lasers to link Muon Space satellites for near real-time connectivity appeared first on SpaceNews.

title: ESA-supported test leads to better in-flight connectivity
summary: Better in-flight streaming and video-calling might just become more accessible thanks to a project supported by the European Space Agency (ESA). Building upon the success of an experiment for a new type of antenna terminal together with ESA, Viasat – a global leader in satellite communications – now plans to commercialise its new in-flight connectivity solution called Viasat Amara.
detailed_news: Viasat plans to commercialise its new in-flight connectivity solution called Viasat Amara. It has a dual-beam phased array antenna that provides both better access to video calling (a latency-sensitive use), as well as video streaming such as watching a football match. This is possible because the antenna can connect to satellites both in low Earth orbit and in geostationary orbit, depending on what is needed.

title: Coming Soon: ESA Student Internships 2026
summary: Are you ready to take your first step into the space sector? The countdown has begun for the launch of the European Space Agency's 2026 Student Internship Programme, and you could be part of it. Applications open the first week of November.
detailed_news: The European Space Agency's 2026 Student Internship Programme opens in November. If you're passionate about engineering, science, IT, business, economics or social sciences, ESA offers a unique opportunity to gain hands-on experience at one of the world's most prestigious space organisations. Applications open the first week of November.

title: Landspace begins final preparations for China’s first orbital launch and landing attempt
summary:
Launch startup Landspace is in the final stages of preparations for the first launch of its Zhuque-3 rocket and a potentially landmark mission for China.
The post Landspace begins final preparations for China’s first orbital launch and landing attempt appeared first on SpaceNews.

title: Sentinel-4 offers first glimpses of air pollutants
summary: The new Copernicus Sentinel-4 mission has delivered its first images, highlighting concentrations of atmospheric nitrogen dioxide, sulphur dioxide and ozone. Despite being preliminary, these images mark a major milestone in Europe’s ability to monitor air quality all the way from geostationary orbit, 36 000 kilometres above Earth.
detailed_news: The Copernicus Sentinel-4 mission has delivered its first images, highlighting concentrations of atmospheric nitrogen dioxide, sulphur dioxide and ozone. Despite being preliminary, these images mark a major milestone in Europe’s ability to monitor air quality all the way from geostationary orbit, 36 000 kilometres above Earth. Ozone high up in the stratosphere plays a crucial role in shielding life on Earth from harmful ultraviolet radiation. But ozone in the lower atmosphere acts as a pollutant, contributing to poor air quality and respiratory problems. Overall ozone levels here are within the expected range. The large-scale distribution, featuring a maximum over the Balkans and Greece and a minimum over the Baltic region, is consistent with patterns detected on the same day.
